intro: Trichostema dichotomum, commonly known as the forked stickflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of pale blue to purple flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as hillsides and coastal areas. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
